The Maker Brand Team The Growth Core Unit is requesting to develop a Maker Brand team to help market MakerDAO to a wider audience and better engage with existing users. Summary If approved, the Maker Brand team will first be incubated with the Growth Core Unit, after which it can propose becoming an independent, self-contained C.U. The proposed changes will be submitted for on-chain voting next week.  Rethinking budgeting for CUs Core Unit budgeting has been a hot topic on the forums in recent weeks. The latest addition to the discussion comes from Recognized Delegate Justin Case, who analyzes the topic into its parts and explores which parts may be most valuable to focus on. Summary @JustinCase begins by identifying the different elements any budget process must balance:  Ease of comparing different budgets to each other Governance overhead of evaluating a growing number of budgets The ability to make meaningful changes to a budget vs. the need to avoid micromanagement and respect C.U. autonomy The need for oversight vs. work demand on reporting and evaluation The risk of providing C.U.s with too many funds that remain unused and unreturned vs. keeping efficient operations and the need for frequent additional budget requests Over- or underutilization of a given core unit given their budget, especially for core units that primarily serve other core units  Next, Case focuses on two areas where improvement can encourage better budget discipline and help ensure resources are spent on more valuable initiatives. Indirect Financing Indirectly financing some Core Units—meaning they will not receive a direct budget but will be funded on an as-needed basis—will help ensure that only the community’s services are funded. Competition Next, Case describes an interesting idea for introducing natural competition to exert downward pressure on budget proposals. By adding redundancy to the organization of Core Units, namely by establishing parallel C.U.s in the same field while also ensuring that neither C.U. can monopolize all the work, C.U.s will compete to provide the best services the DAO at the lowest cost. Like any proposal, this one comes with its advantages and disadvantages. Pros  Greater focus on objectives as they are now set at the protocol level. Increased cost control because Core Units will have to be attractive to win bids for work. Better redundancy because other Core Units can step up and replace others if they cease to function. Less focus on micromanaging Core Units and detailed budget proposals. Increased Core Unit autonomy.  Cons  Increased governance overhead in designing objectives. With individual Core Units reduced in size, they may be less capable of independently moving the protocol forward. Less security for Core Units may lead to detachment from the protocol. Seeking Consensus ‘Yo, do you even signal?’ Set the AAVE D3M DC to 0 (Zero)  Poll Closes on June 20th, 2022, at 17:00 UTC  The current market environment is too volatile, separating the more robust lending protocols everywhere, centralized or not, from those with lower risk standards. Unfortunately, AAVE is currently loaded with risk with large exposure to stETH. AAVE also has a large surface area due to cross-collateralization (unlike Maker), where other borrowers can take out the locked collateral like ETH and WBTC in the protocol. It also operates on multiple chains, which means that it carries exposure to centralized bridge failure risk on all those chains. It’s a risky environment, in general, to extend a 100M Debt Ceiling when the dominant theme is redemption. The AAVE-DAI pool currently has enough reserves right now for MakerDAO to withdraw. If the DAI reserves become empty, any periodic DAI repayments from other borrowers will be snatched quickly by bots, and a protocol like MakerDAO will be locked in for a long time. Any new proposal can carry with it significant legal or regulatory consequences. Actions such as issuing new assets that resemble debt or equity or implementing staking rewards could trigger a review or legal enforcement by official regulatory bodies. As of now:  Legal information or analysis is not required or advised for adding new Core Units. Legal information or analysis is not required or advised for adding any changes to the Maker Protocol via MIPs. Besides collateral onboarding, there are no procedural guarantees or requirements regarding the provision of legally relevant information or legal analysis. MKR holders and the community can verify the legal feasibility of proposals before accepting them, while proponents are provided with a clear procedure and timeframes simultaneously. News and Announcements  Decentralized Voter Committees: Endgame Party calls. Everyone welcome  @rune will again be hosting Decentralized Voter Committee calls on Wednesday and Thursday at 9 pm CEST this week. Wednesday’s call focused on short-term issues and governance organization, while Thursday’s call will focus on the Endgame Plan’s long-term design.  Self Insurance Fund - Update  @layerzero of the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit provided an update on the Self Insurance Fund (SIF) initiative for covering legal and liability risks MakerDAO stakeholders may be exposed to. The SES Legal Research team views SIF as the first layer of a comprehensive legal risk management framework. Active Discussions  Endgame Plan 4: Understanding MetaDAOs  The fourth post in @rune’s series on the Endgame Plan covers a critical topic: MetaDAOs.  MetaDAOs come in three different primary forms:   CreatorDAOs: General MetaDAOs with a very flexible and autonomous scope  GovernorDAOs: Focus on running core governance processes and bureaucratic systems as a service for Maker  ReformerDAOs: Handle everything related to the real world, such as Real World Assets and legal and political outreach  MetaDAOs have multiple avenues available for generating revenue streams:  MetaDAOs also provide a foundation for one of the secondary goals of the Endgame Plan: helping Maker expand to layer-2 blockchains. New MetaDAOs will have an opportunity to stake out exclusive claims to L2s that have not yet been adopted by Maker, opening up further revenue possibilities while helping MakerDAO expand cross-chain.  @rune also hopes MetaDAOs will get involved in the Metaverse, an area where the Maker organization has yet to find a natural entrance. The goal is to foster ways for MetaDAOs to create intangible value, such as achieving higher community activation by running private gaming servers for members, getting involved in NFT curation, or hosting real-world events.  The post concludes with a look at six different MetaDAOs that could help rein in governance complexity and provide tangible benefits for MakerDAO.      DeCap + Quadratic Funding: augmenting the EndGame. Optimal infrastructure funding mechanism for MakerDAO  “MakerDAO is facing the problem of optimal allocation of limited resources towards public goods.” @pvl made a post outlining what they believe is the optimal way to finance MakerDAO infrastructure. One popular solution for managing resource distribution for the funding of public goods is quadratic funding, supported by Ethereum founder Vitalik Buterin and others, which enables voters to signal support for a proposed public good as well as the strength of that support, which can be purchased at an increasing marginal cost. A matching pool (budget) then matches voting results with funds. @pvl introduces the idea of DeCaps (Decentralised/Delegate/Degen Capital) to apply this concept to MakerDAO. A DeCap is defined by:  Delegated MKR Reputation earned from objective data (degree of active involvement in the DAO activities: onchain vote participation, successful MIP authorship, etc.) Subjective peer assessment (delegates/community members/MKR holders give subjective scores)  Each Delegate has their own cumulative, non-transferable, individual DeCap that they vote with and is compensated proportionally to. Using DeCaps, decisions about fund allocation can be made using the quadratic voting mechanism. Under the proposed system, a Global Allocated Budget is designated for a period of time, say three months. Anyone can nominate funding recipients and provide arguments for their nominations. With an individual amount of credits in proportion to their DeCap at the start of the voting period, Delegates allocate their credits based on their assessments of a proposed funding recipient or project’s value. Delegates can also indicate the strength of their opinions by allocating multiple credits to the same recipient at an increasing marginal cost per allocation, thereby implementing the quadratic voting mechanism. The various metrics and variables can be tailored specifically to Maker’s needs. Modeling DAI maturity  @SebVentures of the Strategic Finance Core Unit made a post modeling DAI maturity. A bank deposit is the closest traditional financial instrument to a stablecoin like DAI. TradFi methods of modeling bank deposits, however, are difficult to apply to on-chain assets. Ideally, we would be able to model customer behavior using on-chain behavioral data informed by macroeconomic factors such as bull/bear markets, interest rates, etc. Still, this model would be very expensive and unreliable to generate at the current stage. @SubVentures settled on a simpler model: Create buckets of on-chain addresses, then generate a worst outflow scenario based on historical data. Helping MakerDAO craft a growth strategy mhonkasalo & teemulau believe DAI will become increasingly B2B, creating an opportunity for MakerDAO to become a wholesale DAO-to-DAO lender for any DeFi protocol that distributes DAI. Supporting a scalable DAO model In particular, mhonkasalo & teemulau aim to help address the following concerns:  Maker governance needs more active delegates with enough weight to impact the overall results and drive new initiatives that don’t necessarily originate from Maker core team members. Core Units aren’t always aligned with the interests of MKR holders. Establishing trust between MKR holders and Core Units is key going forward. Maker is currently unprofitable. This doesn’t necessarily mean that resources should be cut, but now is a good opportunity for further analysis to ensure that goals to help Maker scale are being prioritized correctly.  You can learn more about mhonkasalo & teemulau and ChicagoDAO at Meet Your Delegate #13, which will be taking place on June 8 at 5:30 pm UTC. Budget Start and End Dates: Budgets now have a maximum duration of 12 months and cannot start later than three months after being formally submitted.  Budget Composition: Budget requests are now required to provide more specific details  For a more in-depth overview, check out Monday’s Weekly Relay.   The Endgame Plan parts 1&2 MakerDAO co-founder @rune posted a comprehensive overview of his Endgame Plan, a heavily discussed topic on the forums since it was introduced two weeks ago. This post contains the first two sections of a full document to be released in the future. The Endgame Plan is an initiative for completely revamping Maker governance to eventually establish a "predetermined, immutable end state" that is truly decentralized. Some of the shorter-term goals of the Endgame Plan include:  Quickly launching a synthetic ETH product that allows Maker to tap into the Ethereum Merge Incubating a fully-fledged, economically sustainable DAO with significant synergy with Maker  Yield farming the new DAO token to DAI and allowing ETH vault and MKR holders to participate in governance The farming rewards mean this will immediately drive governance participation and help address voter apathy and centralization of governance   Establishing stronger norms and codes of conduct for governance participants, creating a check on the power of Delegates and Core Units  Read About Part 1 Part 1 of the post includes a discussion and explanation of a large array of topics, including: MetaDAOs, the primary tool of the Endgame Plan MetaDAOs will establish dynamics that fit better into a decentralized and transparent ecosystem. They will also allow Maker to measure the value and potential in the ecosystem and the workforce by wrapping tokens around them, then boosting that potential value by seeding a community through the distribution of the tokens.     Read About Part 2 Part 2 of the post, “Endgame Plan Launch,” goes into some specifics surrounding details on how MetaDAOs will work in practice and how the launch will be conducted.   The post concludes by outlining the benefits of implementing the Endgame Plan for Maker stakeholders and Maker governance and growth:       Should Maker Manage Sustainability? What Topics Will Be Most Relevant to Future-Proof the DAO The Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit (SES) partnered with sustainability and impact management expert Dr. Julian Frede to assess key environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks and opportunities for Maker. SES and Dr. Frede produced a report exploring their findings. The team settled on two key questions regarding MakerDAO's relationship to sustainability, which they define in this post as "meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs":  Dr. Frede shared his findings in an interview with members of SES.      The report summarizes approaches to answering a series of important questions, including:   Mapping topics on Maker: Where are the risks and opportunities in the sector? Identifying categories of sustainability topics related to Maker:   CO2 footprint: Managing the major KPI on climate change  Cyber ecosystem risks and developments: Keeping the combination of first-mover and best practices; digital trust is a key element of this category  Financial inclusion: Understanding and promoting the benefits of the Maker customer base to create an inclusive platform for economic empowerment for everyone  Talent & people: Remaining the employer of choice  Regulation: Understanding the reasons for regulation and engaging with governments and regulators  Strategy and processes: Using scientific governance and data-driven management to identify and manage key sustainability topics  Community: Fostering Maker’s engagement with the global community    Dr. Frede also included in his report a sketch of potential next steps on Maker’s road to sustainability:   MakerDAO: Long-term Growth Strategy for the Future of DeFi Several contributors published a forum post outlining their views, continuing the ongoing discussion regarding Maker's overall growth strategy. The authors believe that Maker’s core is the asset base of the protocol. Today, however, this base is not being used to its full potential. It needs to be “invested conservatively but managed productively.”  To grow the surplus buffer to a level where it is capable of absorbing risk when Maker needs it to, the post proposes three “pillars of growth”:  Becoming the first programmatic lender in the emerging DeFi money markets through D3Ms and institutional vaults Becoming the stablecoin of reference for retail users in a multi-chain universe through MCD on Layer 2s/multi-chain and an in-house Maker Teleport system that connects the ecosystem with DAI as the base currency Establishing real-world organic demand, laying the decentralized financial rails that connect crypto and the real world  Building these pillars will require us to:  Invest our assets productively, in accordance with prudent liquidity management Scale our surplus buffer quickly and programmatically, in line with new growth Become the wholesale lender of choice for crypto and the real world alike  Further Details The full post goes into detail regarding ways to achieve these goals, including:         [Discussion] Capital Raise In this post, @Tosh9.0 asks: "Are you for or against the token offering/capital raise pushed by RWA and Growth to fund further protocol development and Dai market expansion?" This thread was forked from a Signal Request post regarding a trial run MIP74: Permissionless Open Market Operations, which defines the process used to agree on and enact permissionless open market operations with funds controlled by MakerDAO. [Informal Poll] Require 2/3 approval to issue MKR or debt In the interest of encouraging Maker contributors seeking to raise money to address issues raised by critics, this poll asks:  That any vote authorizing the sale of MKR requires a 2/3 majority to pass That any vote authorizing the sale of debt, debt-like tokens, or any form of “giving yield” requires a 2/3 majority to pass MKR vesting, flap auctions, DSR, Deco CU, and any other programs already authorized today are excluded from this requirement If passed, the effect expires after six months  Pros  Ensures money is only raised if a substantial percentage of the community is willing to commit to and accept the costs, which also lowers the chances of reneging on obligations Still allows for raising money if needed  Cons  Makes it harder to raise money for the next six months     ‘Yo, do you even signal?’ Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn @rema submits a signal request replacing the previous Signal by Andrew Burban to restart the burn.
